Mar 25

Practical tips for attacking the chicken and egg problem for startup mobile apps

Often the success of a mobile app startup depends on how many users they have. And the problem is that people will sign up on your product only if they see your app provides some value (chicken). On the other hand, your product doesn’t provide value unless there are many users signed up (egg). Examples of such products are Airbnb, Uber, Craigslist, and almost every dating app.

The good news is that chicken and egg problem is solvable, that’s why the above companies exist. So, the first thing that I could tell you is that do not give up and do not get discouraged. If they did it, you can do it as well. Consider it just as another problem that you need to solve to get to your goals.

That said, be realistic. The era of creating an app, publish it on App store, and getting successful is passed. You need to promote and market your app aggressively. You need to have a plan and continuously improve your marketting and growth strategies. In fact most of your energy should be spent on this aspect.

In this article, I will try to give you some practical tips on how to tackle this problem and move forward.

Rather than giving you vague ideas, I try to provide practical example. Most of these tips can be applied for free or at a very low cost.

1. Start with seed users and really tend to them

It’s hard to get 1,000,000 users, but it is easy to get 50 users on low budget. The key is to really tend to your users and give them the best service. Get their feedback, and actually address it as best as you can. Then, send them a message and show them the improved version. Let them know that you are serious and you care.

Build on top of what you have and grow slowly.

Pro tip: Contact one or two of your users who seem more excited about your app, and offer them a gift card in exchange for 15 minutes of their time on the phone to get their feedback.

2. Divide and conquer

Divide the problem into smaller sections and solve them separately. A very common way of doing this is to launch in one or two cities first and to focus on user acquisition only there. Facebook is a very well known example of this approach: They launched in Harvard University first and continued school after school.

3. Promote your app on your own network

You can start with promoting your app on your Facebook wall, Instagram, and Twitter page. Chances are some of your friends and friend of friends will find it useful and sign up.

Pro tip: as you are developing your product, start growing your network. Facebook suggests you to become friends with 100 new people that you don’t know but with whom you have common friends? Do it!

Here are some practical tips on how to promote on your own network:

Post something that ads value to your audience

It goes without saying that posting the same cliche message that promotes your app is useless and it only bores your audience. Eventually they will hate you. Instead, you want to post something interesting. Do some research and find interesting articles and pictures that are related to your app and your audience.

Practical example: Watch this video posted on Facebook by RelationshipRules. This video can be produced in minutes, but it goes a long way. In fact your heart should be made of stone if you don’t click on the like button after watching it!

Regularly post on your blog

Saw something interesting? Came up with and interesting idea? Is it in any way related to your product? Blog time!

Practical example: Check this example on our blog.

  • Pro tip 1: Post on your blog, then post it on your Facebook.
  • Pro tip 2: Blog directly on your Facebook.
  • Pro tip 3: Boost your successful blog posts on Facebook to get more audience.
  • Pro tip 4: To save time, hire someone to write the first draft of your post and find appropriate pictures.

Post links to your blog posts on places like Quora and Reddit

You need to drive traffic to your posts and eventually to your app by promoting your post. A good and free way of doing this is to post it on forums and social networks such as Quora and Reddit in their relevant sections. In fact, I can’t wait for this post to finish to post it there.

Pro tip: Be very careful about what you post on these places. People there don’t B.S. Make sure you know what you are talking about, and that you actually contribute to the conversation. Only post a link to your own material after providing some value.

Practical Example: You can find tons of examples like the image below

Create promotions and contests

You can provide value to many people by just promising to provide value to only one person. This is the essence of contests and raffles.

Here you can find more details and tips about contests.

Pro tip: Keep your promises and act honestly. Actually do award one of the users who participates, and use that opportunity to promote your app even one more time by announcing their name and posting their pictures.

4. Use Instagram

I’m sure by now you know the importance of Instagram. Here are some practical tips to complement that:

  • Post several times of the day on your Instagram page.
  • Smart use of hashtags: pick hashtags that are related to your nitch audience. For example, #love is an abyss. Millions of people post there everyday, and your post will be drowned in seconds. However #loveinsanfrancisco is more limited. By posting into these tags on a regular basis, you can own it, and make it yours.
  • Leave useful comments for other users. I post on Instagram regularly and get cliche comments such as “loved it!”, “great!” or “nice!”. Nobody pays attention to these kind of comments anymore. Instead, find something interesting about that picture. For example: “The choice of red and blue colors in your picture really inspired me”. The idea is to show that you spent time and actually cared about their content.
  • Cross post from your Instagram to your Facebook page.

5. Use Facebook ads

Facebook ads are among the hottest tools these days to get to your quality users. The users you would get are very valuable: as opposed to your mom and your best friend, they signed up because they actually needed your product. Facebook ads are not cheep, and they may not be sustainable, nevertheless, you can get your first 50–100 quality users for a low price.

Facebook ads have become a science now (or so they are claimed) and many people claim they can teach you how to do it. It might be useful to take a course or two in learning how to optimize them, but I would not spend too much money on these courses. You can start with small budget and experiment on your own.

Pro tip: See other ads that appear on your Facebook which seem to be successful (i.e. they have many comments and likes). Get the idea from them and apply it to your own ad.

6. Promote your product at places that your potential users would go

What do your audience do? Do they go to entrepreneurship conferences? Are they young and athletic? Then go to a gym, and ask for a table to promote your app there. Do your potential users go out in bars and clubs? Go there and talk to them. Give them promotional materials and ask them to follow you on Facebook or Instagram.

The idea is to go to those places and provide a valuable experience for people whom you want to get to know you.

Practical Example: We recently went to several dance festivals to promote our app PlusOne Social. All we needed to do was to provide a fun photo booth, and got people’s email address in exchange of the pictures. We were able to sign up many people boost our Facebook likes.

7. Go out and talk to people

There is nothing wrong with becoming a billboard of your product.

Practical example: Wear a T-shirt with a logo of your app. Go to coffee shops, malls, and bars. Start a conversation with people. Give them gift cards, promotional materials, buy them coffee or drinks, and have them install your app and give you feedback.

I work in coffee shops on my laptop all the time. Everyday, I challenge myself to talk to someone else who is also working there and exchange ideas.

8. Continuously educate yourself

There are tons of ways for user acquisition. Don’t limit yourself to just this article. You need to be persistent. Don’t get discouraged because someone turns you down. Do your research, read, watch videos, and apply any tips that you can get from others.

Practical example: Watch this video by the founder of League app, and thank me later.
